Subject: Cleaning
General Patient Text:
Clean high-touch hard surfaces often, using either regular household cleaners or diluted bleach.  
•Click on [[list of approved disinfectants; https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/drugs-health-products/disinfectants/covid-19/list.html]]
•Diluted bleach recipe: 250 mL (1 cup) of water per 5 mL (1 teaspoon) of bleach. Directions are based on bleach that is 5% sodium hypochlorite, to give a 0.1% sodium hypochlorite solution. Never mix bleach with other chemical products and use it in a well-ventilated area.

Subject: Masks
General Patient Text:
•[[VIDEO on how to wear a mask; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/video/covid-19-wear-non-medical-mask-face-covering-properly.html]]
•[[DO's and DON'Ts; https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/hc-sc/documents/services/publications/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-safely-use-non-medical-mask-face-covering/covid-19-safely-use-non-medical-mask-face-covering-en.pdf]]
•[[LIMITATIONS; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html#_Limitations]]
•DO NOT wear a mask with an exhalation valve

Subject: Screening  during COVID-19
General Patient Text: n/a

Subject: Screen men age 65-80 with ultrasound once
General Patient Text: n/a

Topic heading: Aorta: The body's main blood vessel
Subject: Talk to your provider to see if you need a test
General Patient Text:
Your provider may ask for an ultrasound of your belly
to detect a bulge in the main blood vessel 
(the bulge is nicknamed AAA 
for short or
Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm)
If the bulge grows it can burst and cause death.

Subject: Benefits of physical activity
General Patient Text:
Physical activity
prevents heart disease, cancer, depression and [[more; https://www.reframehealthlab.com/23-and-12-hours/]]

Subject: Recommended physical activity
General Patient Text:
The recommended minimum amount of physical activity
is 150 minutes a week of moderate intensity exercise. 
Definition of moderate intensity:
while you are active you have enough breath to say a short sentence but not enough to sing
•[[more info for age 18-64; http://www.csep.ca/CMFiles/Guidelines/CSEP_PAGuidelines_adults_en.pdf]]
•[[more info for age 65+; http://csepguidelines.ca/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/CSEP_PAGuidelines_older-adults_en.pdf]]

Subject: Exercises
General Patient Text: [[Recommendations; https://osteoporosis.ca/bone-health-osteoporosis/exercises-for-healthy-bones/]]

Subject: Bone Density Test
General Patient Text: Below age 65: only recommended if: you have [[risk factors; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/chronic-diseases/osteoporosis.html]]
Health Provider Text: If patient has  [[risk factors; http://www.osteoporosis.ca/multimedia/pdf/Quick_Reference_Guide_October_2010.pdf]] or use [[OST; http://www.cfp.ca/content/61/7/612]]

Subject: Bone Density Test
General Patient Text:
Recommended for everyone 65 or older
Your provider will determine when to repeat it
[[more info; https://choosingwiselycanada.org/bone-density-tests/]]
[[calculator for 10 year fracture risk; https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/FRAX/tool.jsp?country=19 ]]
Health Provider Text:
Recommended for everyone 65 or older:
•[[osteoporosis.ca; http://www.cmaj.ca/content/cmaj/early/2010/10/12/cmaj.100771.full.pdf]]
•Or use [[OST; http://www.cfp.ca/content/61/7/612]]
•Frequency of retesting [[not more than every 2 years; https://choosingwiselycanada.org/rheumatology/]]
[[decision aid; https://osteoporosisdecisionaid.mayoclinic.org/]]

Subject: Prevent Breast Cancer
General Patient Text:
•Limit alcohol (see our substance use info)
•Don't smoke
•Control your weight
•Be physically active (see our physical activity info for this)
•Breastfeed if you are able
•Limit time on hormone therapy
[[more; https://www.mycanceriq.ca/Cancers/Risk]]

Click on this [[link to know if you are at high risk of breast cancer; https://www.cancer.ca/en/prevention-and-screening/reduce-cancer-risk/find-cancer-early/get-screened-for-breast-cancer/at-high-risk-for-breast-cancer/?region=on]]

Mammograms for healthy women below age 50 
with no symptoms, no breast problems
and no additional risks 
is not recommended.
[[risks; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/breast/risks/?region=on]]
[[harms of mammograms; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UZlY6Q4m-MM]]
DISCUSS WITH YOUR HEALTH CARE PROVIDER.

Subject:
Get tested for Breast Cancer 
at age 50-74
General Patient Text:
Get a mammogram every 2 years:
You may need one earlier or more often
if you have risks or symptoms.
[[more; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/breast/risks/?region=on]]

Subject: Age 75 and over
General Patient Text:
Research does not recommend mammograms age 75 and over, 
but if you are healthy you may discuss further testing with your health care provider.

Subject: Prevent and screen for Breast Cancer
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Counsel patients to:
•Limit alcohol (see our substance use info)
•Not smoke
•Control their weight
•Be physically active (see our app info for this)
•Breastfeed if able
•Limit time on hormone therapy
[[a risk calculator for patients; https://www.mycanceriq.ca/Cancers/Risk]]

Screening Mammogram:
•Below age 50: Not recommended
[[canadiantaskforce recomendation; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/breast-cancer-update/]]
[[tool to explain harms to patient; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UZlY6Q4m-MM]]
[[tool to explain harms to patient; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/tools-resources/breast-cancer-2/breast-cancer-risks-benefits-age-40-49/]]
•50-74:  Every 2 years
[[weak recommendation; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/breast-cancer-update/]]
•75+: Not recommended by canadiantaskforce.ca,but:
[[CFP  article 2019 on when to stop screening; https://www.cfp.ca/content/cfp/65/8/543.full.pdf]]

High risk patients:
•Known to have a gene mutation that increases their risk for breast cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, CDH1)
•First-degree relatives of someone who has a gene mutation that increases their risk for breast cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, CDH1), have already had genetic counselling and have chosen not to have genetic testing
•Have been assessed by a genetics clinic (using the IBIS or BOADICEA tools) as having a 25% or greater lifetime risk of breast cancer based on personal and family history
•Have had radiation therapy to the chest to treat another cancer or condition (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma) before age 30 and at least 8 years ago
•First-degree relative (parent, brother, sister or child) of a carrier of a gene mutation (e.g. BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, CDH1) and has not had genetic counselling or genetic testing
•Personal or family history of breast or ovarian cancer suggestive of a hereditary breast cancer syndrome

Subject: AFAB w/o top surgery
General Patient Text: Patient: Mammography q2 yrs from age 50-75
Health Provider Text: Provider: Mammography q2 yrs from age 50-75

Subject: AFAB w/ top surgery
General Patient Text: Patient: Consider mammography q2 yrs from age 50-75 if leftover breast tissue; likely not needed
Health Provider Text: Provider: Consider mammography q2 yrs from age 50-75 if leftover breast tissue; likely not needed

Subject: AMAB w/o top surgery
General Patient Text: Patient: Consider breast exam/ mammography q2 yrs from age 50-75 if on estrogen for more than 3-5 yrs
Health Provider Text: Provider: Consider breast exam/ mammography q2 yrs from age 50-75 if on estrogen for more than 3-5 yrs

Subject: AMAB w/ top surgery
General Patient Text: Patient: Breast exam/mammography q2 yrs from age 50-75
Health Provider Text: Provider: Breast exam/mammography q2 yrs from age 50-75

Subject: Breast cancer screening
General Patient Text: 3rd body breast cancer-patient

Subject:
Get tested for Cervical Cancer 
(Pap test)
General Patient Text:
•Women age 25 to 69  (21-69 in some provinces) if have ever been sexually active,
need to get a pap test every 3 years if results are normal.
[[what is cervical cancer;http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/cervical/cervical-cancer/?region=on]]
[[more; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/cervical/screening/?region=on]]
Health Provider Text:
Women age 25 to 69 (21-69 in some provinces) if ever have been sexually active,
need to get a pap test every 3 years if results are normal.
[[more; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/cervical-cancer/]]

Subject: A Pap test may or may not be needed
General Patient Text: •After age 69 if 3 normal results in past 10 years can stop
Health Provider Text:
Stop after age 69 if 3 normal results in past 10 years.
[[Can Task Force reference; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/cervical-cancer/]]
[[CFP  article 2019 on when to stop screening; https://www.cfp.ca/content/cfp/65/8/543.full.pdf]]

Subject: Other ways to prevent Cervical Cancer
General Patient Text:
•Get the HPV vaccine
recommended between age 9 and 26 
but can be given at any age
•Don’t smoke
•Use condoms
•Limit your number of sexual partners
[[more; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/cervical/risks/reducing-your-risk/?region=on]]
Health Provider Text:
•Recommend the HPV vaccine
(recommended between 9 and 26 
but can be given at any age).
[[Canadian recommendation; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/healthy-living/update-recommended-human-papillomavirus-vaccine-immunization-schedule.html#sum]]
•Recommend no smoking, condom use,
and limiting number of partners.

Subject: AFAB w/o bottom surgery
General Patient Text: Patient: Pap test q3 yrs from age 21-70 (Ontario)
Health Provider Text: Provider: Pap test q3 yrs from age 21-70 (Ontario)

Subject: AFAB w/ bottom surgery
General Patient Text: Patient: Screen if cervix still present (depends on type of bottom surgery)
Health Provider Text: Provider: Screen if cervix still present (depends on type of bottom surgery)

Subject: AMAB w/o bottom surgery
General Patient Text: Patient: No screening necessary

Subject: AMAB w/ bottom surgery
General Patient Text: Patient: Consider Pap test q3 yrs from age 21-70, particularly if neovagina made from penile tissue
Health Provider Text: Provider: Consider Pap test q3 yrs from age 21-70, particularly if neovagina made from penile tissue

Subject: Cervical Cancer Screening
General Patient Text: 3rd body cervical cancer-patient

Subject: Prevent Colon Cancer
General Patient Text:
•Be physically active
•Maintain a healthy body weight, [[bmi; https://www.unlockfood.ca/en/Articles/Weight-Loss/BMI-Calculator.aspx]]
•Be a non-smoker and avoid second hand smoke
•[[more; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/colorectal/risks/reducing-your-risk/?region=on]]
Health Provider Text:
Recommend patients:
•Be physically active
•Maintain a healthy body weight, [[bmi; https://www.unlockfood.ca/en/Articles/Weight-Loss/BMI-Calculator.aspx]]
•Limit the amount of alcohol they drink (see healthy drinking guidelines)
•Be a non-smoker and avoid second hand smoke
•Limit the amount of red and processed meats eaten
•Eat foods high in fiber 
•Limit sitting time
[[Source; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/colorectal/risks/reducing-your-risk/?region=on]]

Subject: Screen
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Age 50-74:
•FOBT or FIT (depending on province) every 2y or
•Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years
•Colonoscopy not recommended in Canada for low risk: 1/2000 risk of perforation, no evidence yet,ongoing RCTs
[[canadian task force; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/colorectal-cancer/]]
[[CFP article on when to stop screening; https://www.cfp.ca/content/cfp/65/8/543.full.pdf]]
FOBT=Fecal occult blood test
FIT= Fecal immunochemical test
•Colonoscopy recommended for high risk patients
Click to see [[Canadian association of gastroenterology guideline 2018; https://www.cag-acg.org/images/publications/CAG_CPG_CRC_Screening_Aug2018.pdf]]

Subject: Get tested for Bowel Cancer
General Patient Text:
Age 50 to 74:
•Do a stool test ("poop test") every 2 years
(see your health care provider for a kit)
•Or do another test called
Flexible Sigmoidoscopy every 10 years 
(not common, discuss with your provider if available)
•Colonoscopy is not recommended if you have no symptoms or family history
of colon cancer.
It has a risk of perforation of the bowel of 1/2000

[[more; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/tools-resources/colorectal-cancer-for-patients-2/]]

Subject: Testing to detect early cancer may not be useful at age 75 and over
General Patient Text:
Most people do not need to be screened at this time, 
discuss with your provider if you prefer to be screened.
[[more; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/tools-resources/colorectal-cancer-for-patients-2/]]

Subject: National Indigenous Diabetes Association
General Patient Text:
•[[National Indigenous Diabetes Association; http://nada.ca/]]
•[[Food and Nutrition; http://nada.ca/?page_id=1563]]

Subject: Prevent Diabetes
General Patient Text:
•Eat a healthy diet
•Be physically active
•Keep your BMI healthy:18.5-24
[[bmi; https://www.unlockfood.ca/en/Articles/Weight-Loss/BMI-Calculator.aspx]]

Subject: Get a blood test for Diabetes if you are at risk
General Patient Text:
You can use a calculator to see if you need one:
[[calculator 1; https://diabetes.ca/about-diabetes/take-the-test]]
[[calculator2; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/tools-resources/type-2-diabetes-2/type-2-diabetes-patient-findrisc/]]

Subject: Screen for Diabetes
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Using a calculator is recommended by the Canadian Task Force and is evidence-based.
Your patient can be emailed this questionnaire or it can be filled in the waiting room.
•[[FINDRISC online calculator; https://qxmd.com/calculate/calculator_236/findrisc-diabetes-risk-calculator]]
•[[FINDRISC pdf; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/tools-resources/type-2-diabetes-2/type-2-diabetes-patient-findrisc/]]

or 
•[[CANRISK online calculator;  https://diabetes.ca/about-diabetes/take-the-test]]
•[[CANRISK pdf  available in different languages; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/tools-resources/type-2-diabetes-2/type-2-diabetes-canrisk/]]

Subject: Prevent falls
General Patient Text:
Bathroom:
•Make sure you have non slip surfaces or mats
•Grab bars, bath seat
•Raised toilet 
•Make sure path is clear from bedroom to bathroom

Home:
•Get rid of loose rugs or make non-slip
•Have good lighting and night lights

Be active:
Tai chi,walking, exercise classes etc

Medications:
Discuss with your provider if your medications can cause falls


[[more; https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/phac-aspc/migration/phac-aspc/seniors-aines/alt-formats/pdf/publications/public/injury-blessure/prevent-eviter/prevent-eviter-e.pdf]]
Health Provider Text:
The American Geriatrics Society
and British Geriatrics Society recommend asking about
falls every year 
[[ref CFP article; http://www.cfp.ca/content/62/9/717]]
[[more info; https://www.ajpmonline.org/article/S0749-3797(18)31759-8/fulltext]]

For advice to patients,
see in our app patient section on Falls.

Subject: Take folic acid
General Patient Text:
Take folic acid: 0.4 to 1 mg a day.
A Vitamin available over the counter in pharmacies.
For women of childbearing age, whether planning a pregnancy or not.
[[folic acid; https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/folicacid/recommendations.html]]

Subject: Get tested for certain diseases
General Patient Text:
Talk to your health care provider 
about getting tested before you are pregnant
for important diseases: 
•Rubella, Hepatitis B, HIV:can affect your unborn child.
•Chicken pox: which can be very serious for you in pregnancy.

Subject: Discuss how your age affects fertility with your provider
General Patient Text:
Women who delay child-bearing are at increased risk of infertility.
Prospective parents, especially women, should know that their fecundity and fertility begin to decline significantly after 32 years of age. Prospective parents should know that assisted reproductive technologies cannot guarantee a live birth or completely compensate for age-related decline in fertility [[more; https://www.jogc.com/article/S1701-2163(17)30936-2/abstract]]

Subject: Preconception health for all women of childbearing age
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
[[Complete preconception health care tool; https://med-fom-obgyn.sites.olt.ubc.ca/files/2019/02/Preconception-Tool_-Nov2015-CEP_.pdf]]

Advise folic acid 0.4-1 m/day 
for all women of childbearing age,
as many pregnancies unplanned 
[[more; https://www.jogc.com/article/S1701-2163(15)30230-9/pdf]]

Screen for:
•Rubella immunity
•Varicella immunity
•Hepatitis B and HIV disease
in women of childbearing age,
[[more; http://thehub.utoronto.ca/family/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/Preconception_Health_Care_Tool.pdf]]

Delayed child-bearing: discuss
•Decreasing fertility for women after age 32 
•Assistive reproductive technologies cannot guarantee a live birth. 
[[more at SOGC guideline 2017; https://www.jogc.com/article/S1701-2163(17)30936-2/pdf]]

Subject: Ovarian cancer
General Patient Text: Patient: Same as cis women/discuss with provider (not all bottom surgeries include oophorectomy)
Health Provider Text: Provider: Same as cis women/discuss with provider (not all bottom surgeries include oophorectomy)

Subject: Ovarian cancer
General Patient Text: Patient: No screening

Subject: Family Planning
General Patient Text: 3rd body Family planning-patient

Subject: Prevention
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Physical activity
more potent than statins in preventing heart disease
see our physical activity section 

Lipid screening: 
•before 40 in men and 50 in women if risk factors 
[[risk factors according to Simplified lipid guidelines see Screening page 2; http://www.cfp.ca/content/cfp/61/10/857.full.pdf]]
[[risk factors according to CCS see Figure 1; http://www.onlinecjc.ca/article/S0828-282X(16)30732-2/pdf]]
NOTE: in women Hypertensive diseases of pregnancy (including preeclampsia, pregnancy induced hypertension are considered additional cvs risk factors see [[link; https://www.jogc.com/article/S1701-2163(18)30836-3/abstract]]
•for men age 40+:repeat every 3-5 years if N
•for women age 50+ or at menopause:repeat every 3-5 years  if N
•age 75 + healthy: discouraged as have not been validated at this age
•[[Canadian Simplified Lipid Guidelines by family physicans;http://www.cfp.ca/content/cfp/61/10/857.full.pdf ]]
•[[Canadian Cardiology guideline; http://www.onlinecjc.ca/article/S0828-282X(16)30732-2/pdf]]

Subject: Be active
General Patient Text:
•[[more info for age 18-64; http://www.csep.ca/CMFiles/Guidelines/CSEP_PAGuidelines_adults_en.pdf]]
•[[more info for age 65+; http://csepguidelines.ca/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/CSEP_PAGuidelines_older-adults_en.pdf]]

Subject:
Get tested for cholesterol
below age 40
General Patient Text:
Only if you have 
some health problems:
•Family history of early heart disease 
•High blood pressure
•Diabetes
•Smoking
•[[and other health problems; https://www.heartandstroke.ca/heart/risk-and-prevention]]
Discuss this with your provider.

Subject:
Get tested for cholesterol
below age 50
General Patient Text:
Only if you have the following
•Family history of early heart disease 
•High blood pressure
•Diabetes
•Smoking
•[[and other health problems; https://www.heartandstroke.ca/heart/risk-and-prevention]]
Discuss this with your provider.

(If your menopause happens before age 50
start testing  for cholesterol at that time.)

Subject:
Get tested for cholesterol
above age 40
General Patient Text: If the blood test is normal repeat every 3-5 years.

Subject:
Get tested for cholesterol
above age 50 for women
General Patient Text:
or at the age of menopause.
If the blood test is normal repeat every 3-5 years

Subject:
Over age 74
testing for cholesterol
may or may not 
be needed
General Patient Text:
•If you are healthy 
discuss testing with your practitioner
(most studies for cholesterol were not done on this age group
,so you may not need it).
•If you have health problems 
some health problems require cholesterol testing
and others do not,discuss with your provider.

Subject: Get your heart risk score
General Patient Text: See your provider and/ or answer this [[questionnaire; https://myhealthcheckup.com]]
Health Provider Text:
Risk assessment 
modified Framingham or [[other; http://chd.bestsciencemedicine.com/calc2.html]]
only validated between age 30 and 74

Get help with websites, groups, phone lines in each province.

Subject: Recommendations
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Recommend the [[app CanImmunize; https://www.canimmunize.ca/en/home]]

AGE 18 and above (ALL ADULTS)
The following schedule assumes the patient has  been vaccinated in childhood
•Td (Tetanus-diphtheria) every 10 years
•Tdap(Tetanus,diphtheria, acellular pertussis or whooping cough):once in your lifetime
•Measles Mumps Rubella:it is advised that  most adults should have  2 doses of this vaccine
•HPV: recommended for all females and males from ages 9 to 26. The vaccine is also safe over age 26. [[more; https://www.reframehealthlab.com/should-you-get-the-hpv-vaccine/]]
•Influenza: is recommended for all adults. For high risk groups see CanImmunize app
•Pneumococcal, varicella,  meningococcal are recommended for some high risk groups seeCANImmunize app

AGE 50+
Shingrix,
Not covered in many provinces
[[more; https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/hcp/index.html


AGE 60+
Zostavax
Covered at different ages in some provinces,
Check your province's immunization schedule

AGE 65+ 
•Pneumococcal 
PNEU-P-23 advised for all immunocompetent,
repeat once in 5 years only if low immunity.
PNEU-C-13 advised for immunocompetent but not covered in most provinces.
BE AWARE OF SCHEDULING CORRECT TIME BETWEEN THESE VACCINES
•Pneu-C-13 vaccine should be provided first followed by Pneu-P-23 vaccine at least 8 weeks later.
•Adults aged 65 years and older who have previously received Pneu-P-23 can receive Pneu-C-13 vaccine if at least one year has passed since immunization with Pneu-P-23 vaccine.

•Influenza yearly

SOURCE: NACI: [[National Advisory Committe on Immunization; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci.html]]

Subject: Get immunized
General Patient Text:
For best information download the [[app CanImmunize; https://www.canimmunize.ca/en/home]]

AGE 18-49:
This schedule assumes the patient has  been vaccinated in childhood
•Td (Tetanus-diphtheria) every 10 years
•Tdap(Tetanus,diphtheria, acellular pertussis or whooping cough):once in your lifetime
•Measles Mumps Rubella:it is advised that  most adults should have  2 doses of this vaccine
•HPV: recommended for all females and males from ages 9 to 26. The vaccine is also safe over age 26. [[more; https://www.reframehealthlab.com/should-you-get-the-hpv-vaccine/]]
•Influenza: is recommended for all adults. For high risk groups see CanImmunize app
•Pneumococcal, varicella,  meningococcal,shingles are recommended for some high risk groups seeCANImmunize app

Subject: Get immunized
General Patient Text:
For best information download the [[app CanImmunize; https://www.canimmunize.ca/en/home]]

AGE 50 and over:
This schedule assumes the patient has  been vaccinated in childhood
•Td (Tetanus-diphtheria) every 10 years
•Tdap(Tetanus,diphtheria, acellular pertussis or whooping cough):once in your lifetime
•Measles Mumps Rubella:it is advised that  most adults should have  2 doses of this vaccine
•Influenza: is recommended for all adults. For high risk groups see CanImmunize app
•Pneumococcal, varicella,  meningococcal are recommended for some high risk groups seeCANImmunize app
•Shingles vaccine: 
Shingrix recommended for 50 and over but you may have to pay for this most provinces not funding yet [[Shingrix; https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html]]

AGE 60 and over:
•Shingles vaccine: Shingrix or Zostavax, your province may cover Zostavax but not Shingrix,discuss with your provider [[more info; https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html]]


AGE 65and over: 
•Pneumococca: Pneumococcal 23 is paid for by your province,Pneumococcal 13 may not be paid for by your province. Discuss with your doctor
•Influenza yearly

Subject: Drug Abuse
General Patient Text:
Get help if you are addicted to a substance/gambling.
Each province or territory has a help line: [[more; https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/substance-use/get-help/get-help-problematic-substance-use.html]]
Health Provider Text:
Help available for patients addicted to a substance/gambling:
each province or territory has a help line: [[more; https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/substance-use/get-help/get-help-problematic-substance-use.html]]:
Screening and counseling USPSTF I (2018) under review

Subject: Hepatitis C
General Patient Text:
The Canadian Task Force recommends getting a Hepatitis C test if  you are in one of the following groups:
(more groups in next tab)
•people who inject drugs or use drugs in their nose

•prisoners or people who have previously been in prison

•people with HIV infection
 
•people who were born, lived or travelled in countries where Hepatitis C is common: 

[[image;images/hepatitis_en1.png]]
[[image;images/hepatitis_en2.png]]
Health Provider Text:
Screen individuals at risk 
•[[CTFPHC 2017; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/CTFPHC_Hepatitis-C_Clinician-FAQ_v10_FINAL-1.pdf]] See risks and map for endemic countries 
•[[Summary  CFP 2019 by Public Health Agency of Canada; https://www.cfp.ca/content/cfp/65/3/195.full.pdf]]

Subject: Hepatitis C additional information
General Patient Text:
Other groups needing a test:
•people who received infected blood products
•people who had invasive procedure with inadequate infection control practices
•people who have had tattoos or piercings
•children born to mothers infected with Hepatitis C
•people with sexual partners infected with Hepatitis C

Subject: Smoking
General Patient Text:
Recommended to quit or reduce.
Get help with websites, groups, phone lines in each province.
[[More; http://www.smokershelpline.ca/]]

Subject: Testing for Lung Cancer
General Patient Text:
Testing with a CT scan (special xray)
for certain smokers or ex smokers
is suggested by the Canadian Task Force,
but no province or territory-wide programs yet in place.
There can be harms so this is being studied carefully.
[[More; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/lung/finding-cancer-early/?region=on]]
Some pilot projects underway, ask your provider.

General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
•Ask all patients about tobacco use, 
•Advise stopping this,
•Use behavioral  interventions
•As needed use approved pharmacotherapy to promote cessation.
[[USPSTF A (2013); https://www.uspreventiveservicestaskforce.org/uspstf/recommendation/tobacco-use-in-adults-and-pregnant-women-counseling-and-interventions]]

Subject: Lung Cancer screening
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Low dose CT scan screening
recommended by Canadian Task Force (CTF)for certain patients 55-74 
BUT no province or territory-wide programs yet,
some pilot projects only in certain areas.
Costs and Harms/Benefits being studied.

Criteria by CTF for inclusion:
•Age 55-74
•30 pack-year history or more
•Currently smoke
•Or have quit less than 15 years ago
•Annual screening, up to 3 consecutive times. 

[[CTF recommendation; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/lung-cancer/]]

Subject: What is Dementia?
General Patient Text:
Dementia is a type of disease 
that affects memory and thinking. 
This is different than memory loss from normal aging.
[[normal aging vs dementia; http://alzheimer.ca/en/Home/About-dementia/What-is-dementia/Normal-aging-vs-dementia]]
Dementia can have different causes:
•Alzheimer's disease
•Vascular Dementia (due to strokes)
•Correctable causes: Thyroid, Vitamin Deficiencies
[[more; http://alzheimer.ca/en/Home/About-dementia/What-is-dementia]]

Subject: Prevention of Dementia
General Patient Text:
•Be physically active
•Eat a healthy diet
•Maintain a healthy weight/BMI
•Don’t smoke or drink excessive alcohol
•Keep your blood pressure, blood sugar and cholesterol in a healthy range
•Stay connected socially
•Challenge your brain with games, learning
•Reduce stress
•Protect your head with a helmet in sports 

[[more; http://alzheimer.ca/en/simcoecounty/About-dementia/Alzheimer-s-disease/Risk-factors]]
Health Provider Text:
Recommend your patients:
•Be physically active
•Eat a healthy diet
•Maintain a healthy weight/BMI
•Don’t smoke or drink excessive alcohol
•Keep their blood pressure, blood sugar and cholesterol in a healthy range
•Stay connected socially
•Challenge their brain with games, learning
•Reduce stress
•Protect their head with a helmet in sports 
[[more; http://alzheimer.ca/en/simcoecounty/About-dementia/Alzheimer-s-disease/Risk-factors]]

Subject: Testing available in certain situations
General Patient Text:
Memory testing 
may be done by your health care provider
as you age,
if you or family or friends are concerned.
Health Provider Text:
Screen with MOCA or MMSE if friends, family or patient report memory issues
[[canadian task force; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/tools-resources/cognitive-impairment-2/cognitive-impairment-clinician-faq/]]

General Patient Text:
To prevent diabetes, obesity, heart disease, cancer and more

Subject: Eat 5 or more servings of vegetables and fruit a day
General Patient Text:
Some sources say 5 servings or more, some say 7
[[what is a serving?; http://www.unlockfood.ca/getmedia/255dbbe6-23cd-4adf-9aba-f18310f09e3d/Handy-Servings-Guide-English-for-web-FINAL-October-2015.aspx)of%20vegetables%20and%20fruit/day]]
Health Provider Text:
Some sources say 5 or more servings, some say 7
[[what is a serving?; http://www.unlockfood.ca/getmedia/255dbbe6-23cd-4adf-9aba-f18310f09e3d/Handy-Servings-Guide-English-for-web-FINAL-October-2015.aspx)of%20vegetables%20and%20fruit/day]] 
[[See evidence; http://jandonline.org/article/S2212-2672(14)01871-1/fulltext]]
No specific  CTFPHC guideline but recommended for preventing diabetes,heart disease, cancer etc 
USPSTF B 2014 for BMI>=25

Subject: Eat whole grains and limit fat, salt, sugar
General Patient Text: Use a [[healthy plate; http://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/eating-nutrition/healthy-eating-saine-alimentation/tips-conseils/interactive-tools-outils-interactifs/eat-well-bien-manger-eng.php]]

Subject: Recommendations
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Physical activity
prevents heart disease, cancer, depression and [[more; https://www.reframehealthlab.com/23-and-12-hours/]]

The recommended minimum amount of physical activity
is 150 minutes a week of moderate intensity exercise. 
Definition of moderate intensity:
while you are active you have enough breath to say a short sentence but  not enough to sing

Subject: References/Handouts
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
•[[more info for age 18-64; http://www.csep.ca/CMFiles/Guidelines/CSEP_PAGuidelines_adults_en.pdf]]

Subject: Frequency and type of physical exam
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
IN PATIENTS WITH NO RISK FACTORS, SYMPTOMS, DISEASES OR MEDICATION:
•Measure blood pressure, height, weight and BMI 
•[["at appropriate medical visits" according to CTFPHC;  https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/hypertension/]]
•[[CHEP guidelines for diagnosis of hypertension; https://guidelines.hypertension.ca/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Diagnostic_Algorithm_2018-online.jpg]]
•[[more info on physical exams; https://choosingwiselycanada.org/family-medicine/]]

•Age 18-39 we are recommending patients see their provider every 1-3 years based on above recommendations, this is not evidence-based, this is not for a head to toe exam.
•Age 40 and above we recommend a visit every 1-2 years as there are more screening tests and  more morbidity, not evidence-based.

IN PATIENTS WITH RISK FACTORS, SYMPTOMS,DISEASES OR MEDICATIONS:
SEE MORE OFTEN

Subject: How often?
General Patient Text:
IF YOU ARE HEALTHY WITH NO RISKS FOR DISEASE:
See your health care provider every 1-3 years

Subject: How often?
General Patient Text: IF YOU ARE HEALTHY WITH NO RISKS FOR DISEASE: see your health care provider every 1-2 years

Subject: What is needed?
General Patient Text:
•Blood pressure
•Height, weight, Body Mass Index 
[[bmi; https://www.unlockfood.ca/en/Articles/Weight-Loss/BMI-Calculator.aspx]]
•Other tests such as Pap Tests for women 
•After 40 more tests required see info in our app

•SEE YOUR PROVIDER MORE OFTEN IF MEASUREMENTS ABNORMAL 
                          
[[more; https://choosingwiselycanada.org/health-check-ups/]]

IF YOU HAVE HEALTH PROBLEMS, SYMPTOMS, RISK FACTORS OR ARE ON MEDICATION
you need a more complete physical exam, more often, discuss with your provider

Subject: Prevent Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs)
General Patient Text: •Get tested for STIs every year under age 25

Subject: Prevent Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs)
General Patient Text:
•Practice safe sex:
use a [[condom or other protection; https://www.cdc.gov/teenpregnancy/pdf/Teen-Condom-Fact_Sheet-English-March-2016.pdf]]

•Get tested for STIs:
if you have a new partner, multiple partners,
if you do not use protection, have an STI, or are otherwise at risk.

•Get tested for HIV at any age.

More info:
[[sexual activity;http://www.sexandu.ca/]]
[[infections; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/infectious-diseases/sexual-health-sexually-transmitted-infections/sexually-transmitted-infections-sexual-health-facts-information-public.html#geninfo]]

Subject: Prevent Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs)
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Safe sex and STI counselling for all sexually active patients.
See patient info for reliable websites.

Testing
•25 years and under screen yearly for chlamydia/gonorrhea if sexually active
[[USPSTF 2014; https://www.uspreventiveservicestaskforce.org/Page/Document/UpdateSummaryFinal/chlamydia-and-gonorrhea-screening]]
•25 and over screen according to risk, see below
•Screen for other STIs according to risk (new partner, multiple partners, serial monogamous relationships,unprotected sex, substance use,sex with blood exchange,sharing sex toys)
•Offer HIV testing to all:
[[Public Health Agency of Canada recommendation; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/hiv-aids/hiv-screening-testing-guide.html]]; supported by USPSTF 2013 and CDC, 
[[CTFPHC recommends only if at risk; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/appraised-guidelines/hiv/]]

Subject: Prevent Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs)
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Safe sex and STI counselling for all sexually active patients.
See patient info for reliable websites.

Testing
•25 years and under screen yearly for chlamydia/gonorrhea if sexually active
[[USPSTF 2014; https://www.uspreventiveservicestaskforce.org/Page/Document/UpdateSummaryFinal/chlamydia-and-gonorrhea-screening]]
•25 and over screen according to risk, see below
•screen for other STIs according to risk (new partner, multiple partners, serial monogamous relationships,unprotected sex, substance use,sex with blood exchange,sharing sex toys)
•offer HIV testing to all:
[[Public Health Agency of Canada recommendation; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/hiv-aids/hiv-screening-testing-guide.html]]; supported by USPSTF 2013 and CDC,

Subject: Prevent Prostate Cancer
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Advise to
•Eat a healthy diet.
•Be active most days of the week.
•Keep a healthy weight.

Subject: Screening for Prostate Cancer
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
•Canadian task force (2014): Do not screen.
[[Canadian patient handout;  https://canadiantaskforce.ca/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/CTFPHC_Prostate-Cancer_HarmsBenefits_FINAL.pdf]]

•US Task Force(2018): Discuss pros and cons with your patient 55 to 69 years old.(C recommendation)
Incorporates more recent research.
[[Excellent video explaining benefits and harms; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tYii98gcejA]]
[[US patient handout; pdf/prostate-cancer-infographic-5.pdf]]

Subject: Prevent Sexually Transmitted Infections (STI)
General Patient Text: •Get tested for STIs  every year under age 25.

Subject: Prevent Sexually Transmitted Infections (STI)
General Patient Text:
•Practice safe sex:
use a [[condom or other protection; https://www.cdc.gov/teenpregnancy/pdf/Teen-Condom-Fact_Sheet-English-March-2016.pdf]]

•Get tested for STIs:
if you have a new partner, multiple partners,
if you do not use protection, have an STI,
or are otherwise at risk.

•Get tested for HIV at any age.

More info:

Subject: Prevent Prostate Cancer
General Patient Text:
•Eat a healthy diet.
•Be active most days of the week.
•Keep your weight at a healthy level.
[[What is prostate cancer?; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/prostate/prostate-cancer/?region=on]]
[[Risks; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/prostate/risks/?region=on]]

For information on testing for prostate cancer (psa test) see our app: male ages 55 to 69, sex and prostate section.

Subject: Testing for Prostate Cancer
General Patient Text:
•In Canada testing for finding prostate cancer early is not recommended.
[[Canadian patient handout; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/2014-prostate-cancer-patient-faq-colour-en.pdf]]

•In the US it is  recommended to discuss testing for prostate cancer with your health care provider.There are some benefits and some harms.
[[Excellent video explaning pros and cons; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tYii98gcejA]]
[[US patient handout; pdf/prostate-cancer-infographic-5.pdf]]

Subject: Prostate Cancer
General Patient Text: Patient: No screening

Subject: Prostate Cancer
General Patient Text: Patient:  Same as cis men/discuss with provider (bottom surgery does not remove the prostate)
Health Provider Text: Provider:  Same as cis men/discuss with provider (bottom surgery does not remove the prostate)

Subject: Prostate Cancer
General Patient Text: 3rd body Prostate cancer-patient

Subject: Contraception (Subject)
General Patient Text: Patient: Any hormonal/barrier methods can used (no contraindications with testosterone)
Health Provider Text: Provider: Any hormonal/barrier methods can used (no contraindications with testosterone)

Subject: Contraception (Subject)
General Patient Text: Patient: Use barrier method (or have partner use hormonal contraception) if no bottom surgery and having intercourse with partner who could get pregnant
Health Provider Text: Provider: Use barrier method (or have partner use hormonal contraception) if no bottom surgery and having intercourse with partner who could get pregnant

Subject: Stop Skin Cancer
General Patient Text:
•Wear protective clothing
•Limit time in the sun (worst time: between 10 am and 3 pm) 
•Wear sunscreen (minimum SPF 30) 
[[More info; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/sun-safety/skin-cancer.html]]
Health Provider Text:
To prevent Melanoma:
Decrease exposure to sun with:protective clothing, sunscreen min SPF 30
[[CTFPHC appraised guideline 2014;https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/appraised-guidelines/melanoma/]]

Subject: See an Optometrist
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Vision screening:
Consensus only recommendation from Canadian Ophthalmol Society 2007
Currently in many provinces this would be done by optometrists
New guideline available soon.

If high risk more frequent screening advised than below.
HIgh risk:African American, high myopia,diabetes or hypertension.

•18-40 every 10 years
•41-55 every 5 years
•56-64 every 3 years
•65 and above every year


[[current guideline under review; https://c2-preview.prosites.com/187380/wy/docs/COSVisionScreeningCPGEng_Feb07.pdf]]

Subject: See an Optometrist
General Patient Text: •Age 18-40: Every 10 years

Subject: See an Optometrist
General Patient Text: •Age 41-55: Every 5 years

Subject: See an Optometrist
General Patient Text: •Age 56 to 64: Every 3 years

Subject: See an Optometrist
General Patient Text: Above age 65: Annually

Subject: Age 18 only
General Patient Text:
•Calcium: 1300 mg/day; Vitamin D: 600 IU/ day
Pregnant or lactating same as above
•Folic acid: 0.4 to 1 mg a day for women 3 months before and after conception or always
[[more information on folic acid; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/pregnancy/folic-acid.html]]
[[take more folic acid if; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/pregnancy/folic-acid.html#a4]]
Health Provider Text:
•Calcium: 1300 mg/day; Vitamin D: 600 IU/ day
Pregnant or lactating same as above
•Folic acid: 0.4 to 1 mg a day for women 3 months before and after conception or always
[[more information on folic acid; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/pregnancy/folic-acid.html]]

Subject: Age 19-49
General Patient Text:
•Calcium: 1000mg/day; Vitamin D: 400-1000 IU/day
Pregnant or lactating same as 18 year old
•Folic acid: 0.4 to 1 mg a day for women 3 months before and after conception or always
[[more information on folic acid; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/pregnancy/folic-acid.html]]
[[take more folic acid if; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/pregnancy/folic-acid.html#a4]]
Health Provider Text:
•Calcium: 1000mg/day; Vitamin D: 400-1000 IU/day
Pregnant or lactating same as 18 year old
•Folic acid: 0.4 to 1 mg a day for women 3 months before and after conception or always
[[more information on folic acid; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/pregnancy/folic-acid.html]]

Subject: Age 18 only
General Patient Text: •Calcium: 1300 mg/day; Vitamin D: 600 IU/ day

Subject: Age 19-49
General Patient Text: •Calcium: 1000mg/day; Vitamin D: 400-1000 IU/day

Subject: Age 50 and above
General Patient Text: •Calcium: 1200mg/day; Vitamin D: 800-2000 IU/day

Subject: All ages
General Patient Text:
Better to get calcium from food rather than supplements.
[[More; https://osteoporosis.ca/bone-health-osteoporosis/calcium-calculator/#page-1]]
If you take a Calcium supplement take no more than 500 mg a day.

Vitamin D:
Taking more than 2000 IU a day of vitamin D should be done under medical supervision 
[[more info; https://osteoporosis.ca/bone-health-osteoporosis/calcium-and-vitamin-d/]]
Health Provider Text:
Better to get Calcium from food rather than supplements.
if supplement needed to consider to 500 mg max
taking more than 2000 IU a day of Vitamin D should be done under medical supervision 

[[more info; https://osteoporosis.ca/bone-health-osteoporosis/calcium-and-vitamin-d/]]

Subject: Osteoporosis
General Patient Text: 3rd body osteopororsis-patient

Subject: Osteoporosis
General Patient Text: Patient: Generally same as cis patients but considered high risk if not on ANY hormones for prolonged periods (e.g. no estrogen or testosterone)
Health Provider Text: Provider: Generally same as cis patients but considered high risk if not on ANY hormones for prolonged periods (e.g. no estrogen or testosterone)
